text:
Hi, 

I have newly installed Tomcat 5.5.23 in a windows Server 2003 SP2 and I have 
realized that catalina is not writing on its logs therefore i cannot see the 
balancing sessions. However, I can see stdout.log and stderr.log files.

NOTE: Tomcat is configured in a cluter and any members of the cluster log into 
that file. 

Is there any solution ? 

Thanks in advance.
creator: osegarra@gencat.net
markt@apache.org
text:
You can't have multiple processes writing to the same file. Please use the users
for more help.

Sorry,

I think I have not explained well in my previous note. 

In our environment we have 4 tomcats 5.5.23 separated in two paris of cluter, 
it is:
NODES W11, W12, W21, W22
W11 and W12 makes a cluster
W21 and W22 makes another cluster

Each tomcat writes in its respective C:\Tomcat5.5\Log directory. They write 
their stdout, stderr, etc files but they dont write their catalina log file.

Thanks in advance and sorry for my missexplanation.
Oscar.
creator: osegarra@gencat.net

text: This is still a configuration issue and therefore belongs on the users list.

text:
Hi, 
Sorry, I don't think this issue is a configuration issue. I have took the 
server.xml of our webappp servers (W2003 SP2) and I have put it in my local 
machine XP Professional.

In my local machine system logged perfectly, in our server it did not. I have 
reinstalled tomcat 5.5.23 in our server and I have started it with the default 
server.xml and system again did not log in the catalina log.

I think this could be an issue related to W2003 SP2.

Thanks a lot

creator: osegarra@gencat.net
text:
Sorry me but, 

I work perfectly on Windows 2003 SP1, in Windows 2003 SP2 it does not work. I 
think this can be an issue related to the Windows Service Pack.

I think users mailing list could not help me with this issue, nevertheless I 
have already tried it.

Have anybody tested Tomcat 5.5 in a W2003SP2? 

Thanks and sorry me for my insistenece.

creator: markt@apache.org
text:
Bugzilla is not a support forum. It is for reporting and tracking bugs in Tomcat.

As your own analysis has shown, your problem is related to the application of
SP2. The issue is not, therefore, a Tomcat one. You don't need help fixing a
Tomcat bug, you need help fixing your broken (as a result of applying SP2)
configuration.

For the third time - use the users list. This is what it is for. You might want
to read http://tomcat.apache.org/faq/tomcatuser.html before you post. In
particular, 
http://tomcat.apache.org/faq/tomcatuser.html#why and
http://catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html before you post.
